elements.content: The photoresponsive viologen unit has been widely used to endow metal–organic materials with photochromic and other photomodulable properties. Herein we report the first examples of the metal–organic materials functionalized by extended viologens (ExVs), of general formula [ML]·2H2O (M = Zn for 1, M = Mn for 2, M = Co for 3, and L is a tetracarboxylate ligand with the p-phenylene-extended viologen spacer). Of the three isomorphic metal–organic frameworks, only 1 is photochromic owing to formation of extended viologen radicals through photoinduced electron transfer (PET). The incapability of 2 and 3 to undergo photochromism can be ascribed to longer intermolecular donor–acceptor contacts, emphasizing the sensitivity of solid-state PET to structural changes. 1 also shows strong fluorescence owing to interligand charge transfer, and the fluorescence can be reversibly modulated and switched on/off in the photochromic process. Furthermore, 1 shows excellent hydrolytic stability and can be used as a sensitive, selective, and recyclable fluorescence sensor for detecting Fe3+ in water. The results demonstrated the great potential of extended viologens as functional units for the design of novel responsive metal–organic materials.

Of the three isomorphic metal-organic frameworks, only 1 is photochromic owing to formation of extended viologen radicals through photoinduced electron transfer (PET). The incapability of 2 and 3 to undergo photochromism can be ascribed to longer intermolecular donor-acceptor contacts, emphasizing the sensitivity of solid-state PET to structural changes. 1 also shows strong fluorescence owing to interligand charge transfer, and the fluorescence can be reversibly modulated and switched on/off in the photochromic process. Furthermore, 1 shows excellent hydrolytic stability and can be used as a sensitive, selective, and recyclable fluorescence sensor for detecting Fe3+ in water. The results demonstrated the great potential of extended viologens as functional units for the design of novel responsive metal-organic materials.

elements.content: Of three isomorphic metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) functionalized with the phenylene-extended viologen unit, only the Zn­(II) MOF is capable of photoinduced electron transfer, showing photochromism and photomodulable fluorescence. The hydrolytically stable MOF is an efficient, selective, and recyclable fluorescence sensor for Fe3+ in water.
elements.clean_text: Of three isomorphic metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) functionalized with the phenylene-extended viologen unit, only the Zn(II) MOF is capable of photoinduced electron transfer, showing photochromism and photomodulable fluorescence. The hydrolytically stable MOF is an efficient, selective, and recyclable fluorescence sensor for Fe3+ in water.

elements.content: Photochromic materials show photoinduced color changes that allow for convenient visual monitoring, and the processes may be concomitant with changes in other properties (luminescence, conductivity, magnetism, etc.). The materials have attracted intense attention for their applications in fields such as optoelectronic devices, optical switches, and optical memory. Among others, redox-active viologen (V2+) compounds (N,N′-substituted-4,4′-bipyridiniums) constitute a special class of photochromic materials, where photoinduced electron transfer (PET) leads to brilliantly colored viologen radicals (V•+). The PET process occurs without bond cleavage/formation and thereby imposes little perturbation on molecular and crystal structures, which is advantageous to reversible photochromism in the solid state. In this context, increasing attention has been devoted to development of coordination polymers (CPs) or metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) using viologen-derived ligands. Taking advantage of the great versatility afforded by coordination chemistry, not only can the photochromic performance be modulated, but also the photoactivity can be integrated with various functions arising from metal ions, metal–ligand cooperation, and the extended structures. However, the general rules that control solid-state photochromism in viologen-based materials are yet to be established. The presence of an electron donor does not warrant photochromism, which seems to rely not only upon appropriate electron transfer (ET) pathways (donor–acceptor contacts) but also upon the environment of the donor and acceptor, such as the interactions with lattice water.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Photochromic materials show photoinduced color changes that allow for convenient visual monitoring, and the processes may be concomitant with changes in other properties (luminescence, conductivity, magnetism, etc.). The materials have attracted intense attention for their applications in fields such as optoelectronic devices, optical switches, and optical memory. Among others, redox-active viologen (V2+) compounds (N,N'-substituted-4,4'-bipyridiniums) constitute a special class of photochromic materials, where photoinduced electron transfer (PET) leads to brilliantly colored viologen radicals (V⋅+). The PET process occurs without bond cleavage/formation and thereby imposes little perturbation on molecular and crystal structures, which is advantageous to reversible photochromism in the solid state. In this context, increasing attention has been devoted to development of coordination polymers (CPs) or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) using viologen-derived ligands. Taking advantage of the great versatility afforded by coordination chemistry, not only can the photochromic performance be modulated, but also the photoactivity can be integrated with various functions arising from metal ions, metal-ligand cooperation, and the extended structures. However, the general rules that control solid-state photochromism in viologen-based materials are yet to be established. The presence of an electron donor does not warrant photochromism, which seems to rely not only upon appropriate electron transfer (ET) pathways (donor-acceptor contacts) but also upon the environment of the donor and acceptor, such as the interactions with lattice water.

elements.content: The so-called “extended viologen” (ExV) units consist of two pyridinium rings spaced by conjugating aryl groups such as p-phenylene and show electron-deficient character similar to the viologen unit. The extension can afford new photophysical properties. For example, the N,N′-dimethyl ExV with the p-phenylene spacer shows strong fluorescence, while N,N′-dimethyl-4,4′-bipyridinium (methyl viologen) fluoresces very weakly. ExVs have been used to construct cyclophanes (ExBoxes) and polymers with interesting host–guest chemistry, redox activity, and photophysical properties. However, in contrast with the wide photochromic studies on organic and hybrid compounds derived from the prototypical viologen unit, photochromism of ExV derivatives is seldom reported, and ExV-functionalized metal–organic coordination materials remain unexplored. We envision that the incorporation of ExVs not only can lead to new photochromic hybrid materials but also can allow for coupling of photochromism with fluorescence properties.

elements.content: With these in mind, herein we reported three isomorphic MOFs with a tetracarboxylate ligand derived from the p-phenylene-extended viologen, formulated as [ML]·2H2O (M = Zn for 1, M = Mn for 2, M = Co for 3, L2– = p-phenylenebis­(1-[[3,5-dicarboxylatophenyl]­methyl]­pyrid-4-yl), (). Strikingly, although the MOFs are isomorphic, 1 is photochromic through PET from carboxylate to ExV2+, whereas 2 and 3 are not. The structural origins of the different photoactivities are to be inspected. 1 also shows strong fluorescence, which in combination with the reversible photochromic behavior leads us to investigate photomodulable photoluminescence. Fluorescent MOFs have attracted much attention as sensing platforms for various analytes, but reusable MOF sensors operating in aqueous media are still rare for the limited stability to water or the analytes. 1 shows excellent stability in water, and we will demonstrate that the compound can sense Fe3+ in water with good sensitivity, selectivity, and recyclability.

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that compounds 1–3 are isostructural two-dimensional (2D)-layer-based MOFs crystallizing in the orthorhombic space group Ibam. Therefore, we chose 1 as an example to illustrate the structure in detail. A coordination layer in 1 is shown in . The Zn­(II) center at the 222 site is four-coordinated with the tetrahedral coordination spheres completed by four equivalent carboxylate oxygen atoms with Zn–O = 1.953(3) Å (a). The L ligand shows 2/m symmetry and adopts a zigzag conformation with the two isophthalate moieties trans to each other with respect to the linear and coplanar ExV2+ tether. Each L links four Zn­(II) ions using its four equivalent and monodentate carboxylate groups, resulting a 2D layer along the bc plane (b). The nearest Zn­(II) ions in the layer are doubly bridged by isophthalates to form a 1D chain consisting of metal-sharing bimetallamacrocycle. Each macrocycle is quasi-planar, but the tetrahedral metal geometry dictates that neighboring macrocycles along the chain are noncoplanar. Adapting to the arrangement, the ExV2+ moieties between the chains adopt two alternate orientations with a cross angle of 82.94(3)°. From the topological point of view, each Zn­(II) is a 4-connected node, and the isophthalate moiety can be regarded as a 3-connected node. Then the 2D network can be reduced to a non-coplanar variant of the 2D net with the point symbol (4.62)2­(42.62.82) (Figure S1).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure

The single-crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that compounds 1-3 are isostructural two-dimensional (2D)-layer-based MOFs crystallizing in the orthorhombic space group Ibam. Therefore, we chose 1 as an example to illustrate the structure in detail. A coordination layer in 1 is shown in . The Zn(II) center at the 222 site is four-coordinated with the tetrahedral coordination spheres completed by four equivalent carboxylate oxygen atoms with Zn-O = 1.953(3) Å (a). The L ligand shows 2/m symmetry and adopts a zigzag conformation with the two isophthalate moieties trans to each other with respect to the linear and coplanar ExV2+ tether. Each L links four Zn(II) ions using its four equivalent and monodentate carboxylate groups, resulting a 2D layer along the bc plane (b). The nearest Zn(II) ions in the layer are doubly bridged by isophthalates to form a 1D chain consisting of metal-sharing bimetallamacrocycle. Each macrocycle is quasi-planar, but the tetrahedral metal geometry dictates that neighboring macrocycles along the chain are noncoplanar. Adapting to the arrangement, the ExV2+ moieties between the chains adopt two alternate orientations with a cross angle of 82.94(3)°. From the topological point of view, each Zn(II) is a 4-connected node, and the isophthalate moiety can be regarded as a 3-connected node. Then the 2D network can be reduced to a non-coplanar variant of the 2D net with the point symbol (4.62)2(42.62.82) (Figure S1).

(c) The interdigitating packing of the layers viewed along the c direction (four layers in different colors are shown). (d) The packing viewed along the a direction. (e) The interlayer π···π stacking and C–H···O hydrogen bonds (C8–H8···O2). (f) The H···π interactions (C6–H6···π).

elements.content: The layers are packed in an offset ABAB fashion with deep interdigitation (c), and there are three types of interlayer interactions sustaining the interdigitation: C–H···O hydrogen bonds involving the pyridinium C8–H groups and the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2); π–π stacking interactions in which the ExV2+ moiety is sandwiched between isophthalate moieties (e); and H···π interactions involving the two H atoms from CH2 groups and the pyridinium or isophthalate moieties (f). The relevant parameters for these interactions are collected in . The packing of layers leaves narrow open channels with a diameter of about 2.5 Å along the a direction (d), which are occupied by disordered lattice water. The solvent accessible free volume is 7.9% after removing the water molecules according to calculations using the PLATON program. No appreciable nitrogen adsorption was detected, as expected from the small dimensions of the channel.

Some selected structural parameters for isomorphous Mn­(II) and Co­(II) compounds (2 and 3) are also listed in . The tetrahedral Co­(II) geometry has been found in a number of compounds, although less frequently than octahedral. The geometry is much less common for Mn­(II) but has been found in spinel oxides, phosphates, and other compounds. The bond distances in 1–3 decrease in the order Mn–O > Co–O > Zn–O and are shorter than the values in corresponding octahedral spheres.

elements.content: The PXRD patterns of the bulk samples of the three compounds are in good agreement with those simulated from single-crystal data (Figure S2), which indicates good phase purity. Thermogravimetric (TG) measurements was carried out from room temperature to 800 °C under air atmosphere (Figure S3). The three compounds exhibit a similar weight loss (∼6.0%) upon heating to 140 °C, corresponding to the release of the lattice water (calcd. 5.2–5.3%). No further weight loss was observed until 350 °C, above which the compounds show different decomposing behaviors. PXRD suggests that the crystalline framework of 1 remains essentially unchanged after water release and is stable up to 300 °C ().
elements.clean_text:
Stability

The PXRD patterns of the bulk samples of the three compounds are in good agreement with those simulated from single-crystal data (Figure S2), which indicates good phase purity. Thermogravimetric (TG) measurements was carried out from room temperature to 800 °C under air atmosphere (Figure S3). The three compounds exhibit a similar weight loss (~6.0%) upon heating to 140 °C, corresponding to the release of the lattice water (calcd. 5.2-5.3%). No further weight loss was observed until 350 °C, above which the compounds show different decomposing behaviors. PXRD suggests that the crystalline framework of 1 remains essentially unchanged after water release and is stable up to 300 °C ().

elements.content: In order to explore the chemical stability, compound 1 was treated with water and different organic solvents including ethanol, acetonitrile, methanol, DMF (N,N-dimethylformamide), and chloroform. PXRD measurements suggest that the framework has good tolerance to these common solvents (Figure S4). The structure is intact even in boiling water, indicating high hydrothermal stability (). Good tolerance to acidic and basic conditions is also confirmed by the PXRD patterns measured after treating the compounds with aqueous solutions with pH = 3–12 (). Considering that the framework is based on mononuclear tetracoordinated metal nodes, the high chemical stability is a little unexpected. The stability can because the low-coordinated metal center is well shielded by four carboxylate groups, and the whole structure is reinforced by the widespread and collaborative hydrogen bonding and π···π stacking interactions.

elements.content: Complex 1 is photochromic. The yellow sample of 1 turns to brownish red (1a) when illuminated by a 300 W Xe lamp (). The brownish red photoproduct is stable at room temperature without a detectable color change for 30 s, but further standing led to slow color recovery, which can be accelerated by heating. Complete recovery to pale yellow occurs in about 1 h at room temperature and in 10 min if heated at 80 °C. The photochromic process was monitored by UV–vis spectroscopy. As shown in a, 1 shows strong absorption bands below 450 nm, the absorbance smoothly decreasing at longer wavelengths. After Xe light irradiation, new bands centered at 490, 535, and 596 nm appeared, and the strongest band at 535 nm tended to saturate after irradiation for 10 min. The spectrum was almost recovered after decoloration, with only minor absorption from residual radicals.
elements.clean_text:
Photochromism

Complex 1 is photochromic. The yellow sample of 1 turns to brownish red (1a) when illuminated by a 300 W Xe lamp (). The brownish red photoproduct is stable at room temperature without a detectable color change for 30 s, but further standing led to slow color recovery, which can be accelerated by heating. Complete recovery to pale yellow occurs in about 1 h at room temperature and in 10 min if heated at 80 °C. The photochromic process was monitored by UV-vis spectroscopy. As shown in a, 1 shows strong absorption bands below 450 nm, the absorbance smoothly decreasing at longer wavelengths. After Xe light irradiation, new bands centered at 490, 535, and 596 nm appeared, and the strongest band at 535 nm tended to saturate after irradiation for 10 min. The spectrum was almost recovered after decoloration, with only minor absorption from residual radicals.

elements.content: Photochromism of viologens is due to the generation of radicals (V•+) through PET. We assume that photochromism of the ExV-derived compound 1 proceeds through a similar mechanism. That is, photoirradiation evokes ET from an appropriate electron donor to ExV2+, generating ExV•+. ESR measurements were performed to confirm the radical mechanism. Indeed, 1a exhibits a strong and sharp resonance signal with a g value of 2.0040 (b), close to that of a free electron (2.0023). The compound becomes essentially ESR silent after the yellow color is recovered. Both pristine and recovered yellow samples show very weak ESR signals, which could be due to a trace amount of radicals induced by natural light. It is notable that the color recovery can occur in either air or nitrogen, suggesting that radical annihilation proceeds through spontaneous back ET rather than quenching by molecular oxygen. The PXRD and IR data of complex 1 (Figure S5) show no appreciable variation after color change and recovery, suggesting that the crystal and molecular structure remains unchanged during the reversible processes.

ESR measurements were performed to confirm the radical mechanism. Indeed, 1a exhibits a strong and sharp resonance signal with a g value of 2.0040 (b), close to that of a free electron (2.0023). The PXRD and IR data of complex 1 (Figure S5) show no appreciable variation after color change and recovery, suggesting that the crystal and molecular structure remains unchanged during the reversible processes.

elements.content: By contrast to the rather sensitive response of 1 to light, the isostructural Mn­(II) and Co­(II) compounds (2 and 3) do not show any visual changes under Xe light. The UV–vis spectra of 2 and 3 also show no changes after irradiation (Figure S6). These indicate that photoirradiation cannot induce ET in these compounds. IR and PXRD measurements suggest that the crystal and molecular structures are also not influenced by irradiation (Figure S7). Therefore, the different photosensitivity of 1–3 can only be associated with the different metal centers and the concomitant differences in the interactions between electron donor and acceptor.

elements.content: It is generally assumed that PET in solid-state viologen compounds occurs through short contacts between some electron donors (D) and the pyridinium units, mainly including Npyridinium···D, (C–H)pyrdinium···D, and πpyridinium···πD. However, it is almost impossible to establish unequivocal criteria because ET is influenced not only by the nature and contact parameters of the donor and acceptor but also by their environments. In compounds 1–3, the potential electron donor is the carboxylate O atom. According to the structural data, the shortest contact between carboxylate O and pyridinium N is 4.566(4) Å in 1, which is too long for ET. However, the short hydrogen-bonding contact from (C–H)pyrdinium to uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen (H···O = 2.203(3) Å) and the π···π interaction between ExV2+ and the isophthalate moiety (interplanar distances 3.158(3) Å) may serve as the ET pathways. The interactions are also present in the structures of 2 and 3 (). However, the H···O contacts in 2 and 3 are longer than that in 1 by 0.020(3) Å or more, and the π···π contacts are longer by 0.046(3) Å or more. Not finding other reasonable structural explanations, we tentatively assume that the longer contacts in 2 and 3 are responsible for their incapability to undergo photochromism. This may suggest the subtleness of PET: quite a slight change in donor–acceptor contacts can have a great impact on the photoactivity. However, the correlation is open to further investigation.

elements.content: Finally, we found that the free ligand [H4L]­Cl2 is not photochromic. Although the structure is not available, we speculate that there are no appropriate pathways for PET. Our results with compounds 1–3 demonstrate that metal coordination is a subtle tool to evoke the potential photoactivity of viologen derivatives.

elements.content: The photochromic properties of 1 open the possibility of modulating photoluminescence by photoirradiation. First, the solid-state fluorescence behaviors of 1 and [H4L]­Cl2 were investigated. The ligand emits barely visible blue light under a lab UV light (365 nm), whereas 1 emits very brilliant cyan light. Consistently, the emission spectrum of the ligand shows a weak and broad band at about 494 nm, and 1 shows a strong band centered at 510 nm (). Therefore, compared with the ligand, the coordination network shows not only enhancement in emission intensity but also a shift in emission wavelength (change in emission color). To understand the changes, the absorption spectrum of 1 was revisited in comparison with that of the ligand (). Compared with the ligand (faint yellow), the visible-light absorption of 1 (yellow) shows a significant red shift, which suggests the formation of a ground-state charge-transfer (CT) complex in 1. The possibility of ligand-to-metal CT can be precluded because Zn-carboxylate compounds are usually colorless. The most feasible assignment is interligand CT, which is supported by the π···π interaction between the ExV2+ (acceptor) and isophthalate (donor) moieties from different ligands (d). The excitation of 1 at 462 nm corresponds to its strong CT absorption, but the ligand shows very weak absorption at this wavelength. Therefore, it is most likely that the enhanced and red-shifted emission observed for 1 mainly arises from the ground-state CT complex formed between isophthalate and ExV2+. It is the CT complex that is excited to generate an emissive state.
elements.clean_text:
Photomodulable Photoluminescence

The photochromic properties of 1 open the possibility of modulating photoluminescence by photoirradiation. First, the solid-state fluorescence behaviors of 1 and [H4L]Cl2 were investigated. The ligand emits barely visible blue light under a lab UV light (365 nm), whereas 1 emits very brilliant cyan light. Consistently, the emission spectrum of the ligand shows a weak and broad band at about 494 nm, and 1 shows a strong band centered at 510 nm (). Therefore, compared with the ligand, the coordination network shows not only enhancement in emission intensity but also a shift in emission wavelength (change in emission color). To understand the changes, the absorption spectrum of 1 was revisited in comparison with that of the ligand (). Compared with the ligand (faint yellow), the visible-light absorption of 1 (yellow) shows a significant red shift, which suggests the formation of a ground-state charge-transfer (CT) complex in 1. The possibility of ligand-to-metal CT can be precluded because Zn-carboxylate compounds are usually colorless. The most feasible assignment is interligand CT, which is supported by the π⋅⋅⋅π interaction between the ExV2+ (acceptor) and isophthalate (donor) moieties from different ligands (d). The excitation of 1 at 462 nm corresponds to its strong CT absorption, but the ligand shows very weak absorption at this wavelength. Therefore, it is most likely that the enhanced and red-shifted emission observed for 1 mainly arises from the ground-state CT complex formed between isophthalate and ExV2+. It is the CT complex that is excited to generate an emissive state.

elements.clean_text: 4  Solid-state emission (solid lines), excitation (dotted lines), and absorption (dashed lines) spectra of 1 (red, λex = 462 nm and λem = 510 nm) and [H4L]Cl2 (blue, λex = 425 nm and λem = 495 nm). The inset shows the color of the samples under natural and UV light.

elements.content: The changes in fluorescence were monitored during the photochromic process of 1. As shown in a, concomitant with color change after Xe-light irradiation, the emission becomes invisible under UV light. After irradiation by Xe light for 10 s, the emission intensity dramatically decreases by 36%, and the quenching efficiency reaches 90% after 10 min. This phenomenon of photoinduced fluorescence quenching is because PET from carboxylate to ExV2+ transforms the emissive CT complexes into nonemissive radical species. Considering the good overlap between the emission band and the new absorption bands of the radical phase, energy transfer to radicals can also contribute to the quenching. Concomitant with decoloration, the emission of 1 can recover to the original intensity. The reversible chromogenic and fluorescence off-on switching has been repeated for six cycles without a significant decrease in contrast (b). The photomodulable photoluminescence properties have potential applications in photosensitive and photoswitching optical devices operated with dual light inputs.

elements.content: The strong fluorescence of compound 1 and its high stability in water encourage us to explore its capability of sensing metal ions in aqueous media. For the initial screening tests, the ground samples of 1 were suspended in 10–3 M H2O solutions containing MCl x (M = Na+, K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Cd2+, Ni2+, Co2+, Mn2+, Cu2+, Al3+, Cr3+, and Fe3+). As shown in , only Fe3+ shows a significant quenching effect on the luminescence of 1, with a high quenching efficiency of 93.8% (defined by (1 – I/I 0) × 100%), where I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities before and after addition of the analyte, respectively. The results indicate that 1 has a high selectivity for the recognition and detection specific of Fe3+ ions. To investigate the sensing sensitivity toward Fe3+, the emission spectra of 1 dispersed in H2O were monitored while Fe3+ was gradually added. With the Fe3+ concentration in the dispersion varying in the range of 10–6–10–3 M, the emission intensity decreases (a). There is a good linear correlation (R 2 = 0.995) between the relative luminescence intensity and the amount of Fe3+ ions in the low concentration range (b), following the Stern–Volmer (SV) equation, I 0/I = 1 + K SV[Fe3+], The quenching constant K SV is 4.67 × 104 M–1, which is higher than many reported MOFs. In addition, the detection limit of the assay calculated from 3s/k (k: slope, s: standard) is about 0.92 μM.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Sensing Properties

The strong fluorescence of compound 1 and its high stability in water encourage us to explore its capability of sensing metal ions in aqueous media. For the initial screening tests, the ground samples of 1 were suspended in 10-3 M H2O solutions containing MCl x  (M = Na+, K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Cd2+, Ni2+, Co2+, Mn2+, Cu2+, Al3+, Cr3+, and Fe3+). As shown in , only Fe3+ shows a significant quenching effect on the luminescence of 1, with a high quenching efficiency of 93.8% (defined by (1 - I/I 0) × 100%), where I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities before and after addition of the analyte, respectively. The results indicate that 1 has a high selectivity for the recognition and detection specific of Fe3+ ions. To investigate the sensing sensitivity toward Fe3+, the emission spectra of 1 dispersed in H2O were monitored while Fe3+ was gradually added. With the Fe3+ concentration in the dispersion varying in the range of 10-6-10-3 M, the emission intensity decreases (a). There is a good linear correlation (R 2 = 0.995) between the relative luminescence intensity and the amount of Fe3+ ions in the low concentration range (b), following the Stern-Volmer (SV) equation, I 0/I = 1 + K SV[Fe3+], The quenching constant K SV is 4.67 × 104 M-1, which is higher than many reported MOFs. In addition, the detection limit of the assay calculated from 3s/k (k: slope, s: standard) is about 0.92 μM.

elements.content: The possible interference from other metal ions was checked. As shown in Figure S9, the response of the suspension of 1 to Fe3+ in the presence of a different metal ions is similar to the response to a pure Fe3+ solution, suggesting a fairly good antijamming capability for a wide range of metal ions. In addition, no significant difference was observed when using Fe­(NO3)3, FeCl3, and Fe­(ClO4)3 as the metal source for detection (Figure S10), suggesting that the sensing properties is independent of the anions.
elements.clean_text: The possible interference from other metal ions was checked. As shown in Figure S9, the response of the suspension of 1 to Fe3+ in the presence of a different metal ions is similar to the response to a pure Fe3+ solution, suggesting a fairly good antijamming capability for a wide range of metal ions. In addition, no significant difference was observed when using Fe(NO3)3, FeCl3, and Fe(ClO4)3 as the metal source for detection (Figure S10), suggesting that the sensing properties is independent of the anions.

elements.content: When the environmental issues and the cost of material synthesis are considered, it is highly desirable that the sensing materials can be reused through simple regeneration methods. Compound 1 after Fe3+ sensing use in aqueous dispersions was easily recovered by centrifugation and washing with water. In the four cycles of sensing tests, the recovered samples show no significant differences from the fresh sample in the emission intensity and in the response to Fe3+ (Figure S11). The good recyclability of 1 is thanks to its excellent stability in water. The framework shows no significant degradation in crystalline integrity after the four detection cycles, as confirmed by PXRD (Figure S12). Furthermore, the supernatant obtained after centrifuging the aqueous dispersion of 1 shows no appreciable emission (Figure S13). Therefore, no emissive species is leached into water, and the emission of the dispersion arises from the suspended particles of the MOF. All the results reveal that the MOF could be employed as a sensitive, selective, and recyclable fluorescence sensor for detecting Fe3+ in water.
elements.clean_text: When the environmental issues and the cost of material synthesis are considered, it is highly desirable that the sensing materials can be reused through simple regeneration methods. Compound 1 after Fe3+ sensing use in aqueous dispersions was easily recovered by centrifugation and washing with water. In the four cycles of sensing tests, the recovered samples show no significant differences from the fresh sample in the emission intensity and in the response to Fe3+ (Figure S11). The good recyclability of 1 is thanks to its excellent stability in water. The framework shows no significant degradation in crystalline integrity after the four detection cycles, as confirmed by PXRD (Figure S12). Furthermore, the supernatant obtained after centrifuging the aqueous dispersion of 1 shows no appreciable emission (Figure S13). Therefore, no emissive species is leached into water, and the emission of the dispersion arises from the suspended particles of the MOF. All the results reveal that the MOF could be employed as a sensitive, selective, and recyclable fluorescence sensor for detecting Fe3+ in water.

elements.content: Finally, we remark on the possible Fe3+-sensing mechanism. The stability and recyclability of 1 exclude the mechanism that the emissive framework collapses or undergoes metal exchange. The UV–vis absorption spectra of various metal ions in water were measured and compared with the excitation and emission spectra of the dispersion of 1 (Figure S14). The Fe3+ solution shows no absorption in the emission wavelength range of 1, so the radiative and nonradiative energy transfer from 1 to Fe3+ can be ruled out. However, there is a great overlap between the absorption of the Fe3+ solution and the excitation spectrum of 1. This strongly suggests a competitive adsorption of excitation energy between Fe3+ and 1. For comparison, the other metal ions show no absorption significantly overlapping with the excitation or emission bands of 1, justifying the selective fluorescence quenching by Fe3+.
elements.clean_text: Finally, we remark on the possible Fe3+-sensing mechanism. The stability and recyclability of 1 exclude the mechanism that the emissive framework collapses or undergoes metal exchange. The UV-vis absorption spectra of various metal ions in water were measured and compared with the excitation and emission spectra of the dispersion of 1 (Figure S14). The Fe3+ solution shows no absorption in the emission wavelength range of 1, so the radiative and nonradiative energy transfer from 1 to Fe3+ can be ruled out. However, there is a great overlap between the absorption of the Fe3+ solution and the excitation spectrum of 1. This strongly suggests a competitive adsorption of excitation energy between Fe3+ and 1. For comparison, the other metal ions show no absorption significantly overlapping with the excitation or emission bands of 1, justifying the selective fluorescence quenching by Fe3+.

elements.content: In summary, the first examples of metal–organic coordination solids functionalized by the extended viologens have been synthesized and structurally characterized. Of the three isomorphic MOFs, only 1 shows reversible photochromism because of radical formation through PET. The non-photochromic nature of 2 and 3 is tentatively correlated to slightly longer intermolecular donor–acceptor contacts. The PET activity of 1 also allows reversible switching of its fluorescence by means of photoirradiation. Benefiting from its strong fluorescence and its excellent stability in water, 1 shows good sensitivity, selectivity, and recyclability in sensing Fe3+ in water. The work demonstrates that extended viologens are very useful units for constructing functional metal–organic materials. The large library of extended viologens can afford great potential for the development of novel advanced photofunctional materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, the first examples of metal-organic coordination solids functionalized by the extended viologens have been synthesized and structurally characterized. Of the three isomorphic MOFs, only 1 shows reversible photochromism because of radical formation through PET. The non-photochromic nature of 2 and 3 is tentatively correlated to slightly longer intermolecular donor-acceptor contacts. The PET activity of 1 also allows reversible switching of its fluorescence by means of photoirradiation. Benefiting from its strong fluorescence and its excellent stability in water, 1 shows good sensitivity, selectivity, and recyclability in sensing Fe3+ in water. The work demonstrates that extended viologens are very useful units for constructing functional metal-organic materials. The large library of extended viologens can afford great potential for the development of novel advanced photofunctional materials.

The synthesis of [H4L]­Cl2 was described in the Supporting Information.

Synthesis of [ZnL]·2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

0.05 mmol of ZnCl2 and 7.0 mg of [H4L]­Cl2 were mixed in H2O–CH3CN (8.0 mL, v/v = 2/6) and was stirred for 25 min. The suspension was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel reactor and kept in 140 °C for 48 h. The yellow crystals were isolated, rinsed by H2O, and dried in air at room temperature. The yield was 63%, determined based on [H4L]­Cl2. Anal. Calcd for C34H26N2O10Zn: C, 59.36; H, 3.80; N, 4.07. Found: C, 59.16; H, 3.68; N, 4.03%. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3261br, 3121w, 1630s, 1575s, 1494m, 1469s, 1402w, 1366s, 1301m, 1234m, 1164s, 913w, 875m, 831s, 776s, 736w, 613w, 507w.

elements.clean_text:
Photochromic Experiments

A CEL-HXUV300 300W xenon lamp system (Ceaulight, China) equipped with an IR filter was used for photochromic studies. The distance between the sample and the Xe lamp was set at 22 cm. The solid-state UV-vis diffusive reflectance and fluorescence spectra were recorded using the same sample after irradiation for the given time.

elements.content: The aqueous solutions of metal ions (1.0 × 10–3 mol L–1, MCl x , with M = Na+, K+, Ca2+, Mg2+, Co2+, Cu2+, Ni2+, Mn2+, Cd2+, Al3+, Cr3+, and Fe3+) were prepared. For fluorescence experiments, a finely ground sample of 1 (2.0 mg) was soaked in 3 mL of H2O and sonicated for 0.5 h to form a uniform dispersion, and a given volume of the aqueous metal-ion solution was added. The mixture was further sonicated for 0.5 h and then subject to fluorescence measurements.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Sensing Experiments

The aqueous solutions of metal ions (1.0 × 10-3 mol L-1, MCl x , with M = Na+, K+, Ca2+, Mg2+, Co2+, Cu2+, Ni2+, Mn2+, Cd2+, Al3+, Cr3+, and Fe3+) were prepared. For fluorescence experiments, a finely ground sample of 1 (2.0 mg) was soaked in 3 mL of H2O and sonicated for 0.5 h to form a uniform dispersion, and a given volume of the aqueous metal-ion solution was added. The mixture was further sonicated for 0.5 h and then subject to fluorescence measurements.

cln_elements.content:
The synthesis of [H4L]­Cl2 was described in the Supporting Information.

Synthesis of [ZnL]·2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

0.05 mmol of ZnCl2 and 7.0 mg of [H4L]­Cl2 were mixed in H2O–CH3CN (8.0 mL, v/v = 2/6) and was stirred for 25 min. The suspension was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel reactor and kept in 140 °C for 48 h. The yellow crystals were isolated, rinsed by H2O, and dried in air at room temperature. The yield was 63%, determined based on [H4L]­Cl2. Anal. Calcd for C34H26N2O10Zn: C, 59.36; H, 3.80; N, 4.07. Found: C, 59.16; H, 3.68; N, 4.03%. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3261br, 3121w, 1630s, 1575s, 1494m, 1469s, 1402w, 1366s, 1301m, 1234m, 1164s, 913w, 875m, 831s, 776s, 736w, 613w, 507w.

Synthesis of [MnL]·2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

The preparation of 2 is similar to that of 1 except that ZnCl2 was replaced by MnCl2·4H2O (0.10 mmol, 0.024 g). Yellow crystals were isolated in a yield of 40% based on [H4L]­Cl2. Anal. Calc. for C34H26N2O10Mn: C, 60.27; H, 3.87; N, 4.13. Found: C, 60.21; H, 3.388; N, 4.25%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3263br, 3120w, 1630s, 1610m, 1578m, 1469s, 1402m, 1366m, 1301m, 1234m, 1164m, 913m, 875m, 831m, 776s, 736w, 613w, 507w.

Synthesis of [CoL]·2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

The preparation of 3 is similar to that of 1, except that ZnCl2 was replaced by CoCl2·6H2O (0.050 mmol, 0.012g). Blue crystals were isolated in a yield of 35% based on [H4L]­Cl2. Anal. Calc. for C34H26N2O10Co: C, 59.92; H, 3.84; N, 4.11. Found: C, 60.01; H, 3.53; N, 4.06%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3265br, 3122w, 1631s, 1611m, 1573m, 1469s, 1402m, 1366m, 1302m, 1234m, 1167m, 913m, 875m, 831m, 777s, 736w, 616w, 507w.

cln_elements.content: The PXRD patterns of the bulk samples of the three compounds are in good agreement with those simulated from single-crystal data (Figure S2), which indicates good phase purity. Thermogravimetric (TG) measurements was carried out from room temperature to 800 °C under air atmosphere (Figure S3). The three compounds exhibit a similar weight loss (∼6.0%) upon heating to 140 °C, corresponding to the release of the lattice water (calcd. 5.2–5.3%). No further weight loss was observed until 350 °C, above which the compounds show different decomposing behaviors. PXRD suggests that the crystalline framework of 1 remains essentially unchanged after water release and is stable up to 300 °C ().
cln_elements.clean_text:
Stability

The PXRD patterns of the bulk samples of the three compounds are in good agreement with those simulated from single-crystal data (Figure S2), which indicates good phase purity. Thermogravimetric (TG) measurements was carried out from room temperature to 800 °C under air atmosphere (Figure S3). The three compounds exhibit a similar weight loss (~6.0%) upon heating to 140 °C, corresponding to the release of the lattice water (calcd. 5.2-5.3%). No further weight loss was observed until 350 °C, above which the compounds show different decomposing behaviors. PXRD suggests that the crystalline framework of 1 remains essentially unchanged after water release and is stable up to 300 °C ().
